awd_titl_txt: Janus Liposomes: Formation, Self-Assembly and Controlled Motion
awd_abstract_narration:
Liposomes are small spherical particles of lipid bilayer(s) self-assembled in water. Ever since their discovery in the 1960s, liposomes have proved to be an enabling tool in fundamental research (e.g., cell biology, biophysics and biotechnology) and invaluable material in industry (e.g., food, drug delivery and cosmetics). With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Professor Zhan of Auburn University is developing a new type of liposomes - Janus liposomes. Unlike conventional (symmetrical) liposomes, Janus liposomes contain two opposing halves with different chemical identity and surface characteristics. Professor Zhan's research focuses on  harnessing the unique properties of Janus liposomes to create new lipid materials with advanced functionality. Professor Zhan is also creating new opportunities for high school students and underrepresented college students in the region to participate in research on lipid materials and self-assembly chemistry. Professor Zhan's work aims to make discoveries with significant scientific and industrial impact and to help nurture next-generation workers who have advanced skills in a key branch of chemistry.

Janus liposomes display heterogeneous surface chemistry and broken symmetry, properties distinct from those of conventional liposomes. These unique attributes fundamentally alter the ways Janus liposomes interact with each other and with the surrounding media, which have yet to be explored and understood. To this end, Professor Zhan studies the preparation, self-assembly and motional behavior of Janus liposomes. In the first direction, Professor Zhan is developing a general method to prepare Janus liposomes in batch quantity. This new method helps to remove a bottleneck hampering the advancement of a promising new area and can enable other interested researchers to make contributions to this field. In addition, he is also using Janus liposomes to build complex lipid architectures via self-assembly and to achieve their controlled motion through selective functionalization of specific lipid domains. These activities begin to provide a detailed understanding on the self-assembly of Janus liposomes and establish several robust methods to drive, direct and control motion of aqueous-suspended Janus liposomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Summary.  With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry at National Science Foundation, Professor Zhan and his team at Auburn University have developed and studied Janus liposomes. Liposomes are small spherical particles of lipid bilayer(s) self-assembled in water. Ever since their discovery in the 1960s, liposomes have proved to be an enabling tool and invaluable material both in fundamental research (e.g., cell biology, biophysics and biomaterials) and in industry (e.g., food, drug delivery and cosmetics). Janus liposomes, on the other hand, represent a new type of liposomes, in that they display two opposing halves carrying different surface chemistry ? hence their name after the Roman god of change and duality. In this funding period, the Zhan group has made considerable progress on the preparation, self-assembly and motional behavior of these heterogeneous colloidal particles. Moreover, the Zhan group has also developed new outreach programs, offering hands-on research experiences on lipid self-assembly to high school students and underrepresented college students in the region. The associated merit and impacts of this project are detailed further below.

Intellectual Merit. The Zhan group at Auburn University has pioneered the development of Janus liposomes as a new class of lipid-assembled materials. They have recently demonstrated, for example, 1) A general procedure enabling rapid preparation of unilamellar Janus liposomes in high yields and with size control, 2) Dipolar Janus liposomes ? liposomes that contain opposite surface charges decorating the two halves of the same colloidal body, for the first time, and 3) Heterogeneous, domain-specific assembly and electrostatic/electrokinetic motion of these asymmetrical lipid particles. These discoveries unequivocally demonstrate the broken symmetry of Janus liposomes as a rich avenue for exploring new chemistry (for example, as colloidal building blocks) and applications (for example, as lipid-assembled micromotors).

Broader Impacts. At the center of this NSF-funded project lies the research subject, liposomes, which are being used not only by thousands of researchers daily and worldwide, but also in countless formulas spanning multiple industrial sectors. In this regard, discoveries enabled by this research will have immediate and far-reaching impacts on the scientific community, industry and our society. On the education front, furthermore, Dr. Zhan has mentored 2 Ph.D. and 2 undergraduate students. Outside his lab, he has been actively involved in promoting STEM research in K-12 students as well as at HBCUs.

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2021
Modified by: Wei Zhan
